reasoning:
Essay A is demonstrably superior across nearly all aspects of Criterion B. Its research question, "To what extent is there a relationship between the temperature... of various citrus juices... and their vitamin C... concentration...?" is sharply focused, measurable, and establishes a clear relationship between well-defined variables. In contrast, Essay B's "Investigating the caffeine content... in different brands of black tea..." is more of a title than a testable question. Essay A's background information provides a cohesive scientific context, logically connecting the properties of ascorbic acid to the principles of redox titration. Essay B's background, while containing relevant information on dichloromethane and caffeine, reads more like a series of disconnected definitions.

A significant point of differentiation is the hypothesis. Essay A's hypothesis ("The concentration of vitamin C... decreases with an increase in temperature") is grounded in scientific literature, citing the known instability and degradation pathways of ascorbic acid. Essay B's hypothesis ("I predict that the Tetley Black Tea will have the highest caffeine level... because I always have a heightened level of alertness and concentration after drinking this tea") is purely anecdotal and lacks any scientific rationale. Furthermore, Essay A's methodology is more rigorous, consistently listing equipment with uncertainties (e.g., "100 mL burette (± 0.1 mL)"), which is a key feature of a well-planned investigation. Finally, Essay A presents a comprehensive section on safety, ethical, and environmental considerations, addressing everything from chemical handling and burns to food waste and energy consumption. Essay B's equivalent section is critically incomplete, focusing only on the safety of dichloromethane while entirely omitting any ethical or environmental discussion.

Essay A\'s hypothesis ("The concentration of vitamin C... decreases with an increase in temperature") is grounded in scientific literature, citing the known instability and degradation pathways of ascorbic acid. Essay B\'s hypothesis ("I predict that the Tetley Black Tea will have the highest caffeine level... because I always have a heightened level of alertness and concentration after drinking this tea") is purely anecdotal and lacks any scientific rationale. Furthermore, Essay A\'s methodology is more rigorous, consistently listing equipment with uncertainties (e.g., "100 mL burette (± 0.1 mL)"), which is a key feature of a well-planned investigation. Finally, Essay A presents a comprehensive section on safety, ethical, and environmental considerations, addressing everything from chemical handling and burns to food waste and energy consumption. Essay B\'s equivalent section is critically incomplete, focusing only on the safety of dichloromethane while entirely omitting any ethical or environmental discussion.',
    decision='essay_a'
